Research has shown that diverse types of music education activities and programs can be beneficial to students. However, some types of music education may have a more significant impact on students' academic and social development when compared to others.

For example, music education programs that include active participation, such as playing an instrument, singing, or composing music, tend to have greater benefits than passive activities, such as listening or watching performances. Furthermore, studies suggest that participation in a music ensemble, choir, or band can lead to improvements in teamwork, discipline, and social interaction compared to individual practice.

Additionally, music education programs that focus on improving music literacy, such as learning to read sheet music, can also have a significant impact on cognitive development.

In conclusion, while there is no one specific type of music education that is more effective than the others, research indicates that music programs that involve active participation, music ensemble or band, and music literacy tend to offer the most significant benefits.
